name: Dress to impress
description: In The Great, Peter and Catherine’s costumes during their Dacha visit are designed to demonstrate their unity, as they negotiate with the Swedish royals. Clothes have long been a way to communicate power, particularly in politics.

key_work.title: Catherine and Peter's Dacha costumes
key_work.brief_description: The Great’s two main characters may be married, but Peter and Catherine do not get along, something that’s routinely expressed through costume. In almost every scene, they’re in opposing colours: Catherine in pale greens and yellows that suggest her innocence before joining the Russian court, which Peter starkly contrasts in brooding jewel tones and darker colours. But in the episode “Meatballs at the Dacha”, for a brief moment, they’re aligned, in both story and costume. Each want to broker peace with Sweden, and Catherine’s political savvy is an invaluable counterpoint to Peter’s reckless bravado. Is it love? No, but it might be a winning strategy / works, just like Emma Fryer’s costume designs.

end.title: Cleopatra
end.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille, Adolph Zukor and Paramount Pictures
end.brief_description: Cleopatra is illustrative of the conception of historical epic as charade in which the stars are not only cast as famous historical figures but historical figures are cast as stars (Cleopatra as Colbert). What is absent here is De Mille’s characteristic combination of spectacle and morality play. Instead, the spectacle of a sexual extravaganza, (epitomised by the seduction of Mark Antony on the Royal Barge), verges on self parody. This is held in check only by De Mille’s commitment to conventions of realist stage melodrama, (from his formative years in the theatre), allied with a strong pictorial sensibility. Stars Claudette Colbert, Henry Wilcoxon, Warren William. From an adaptation of historical marterial by Bartlett Cormack.

links.description: Elizabeth Taylor might not have been royalty technically, but like Cleopatra herself, she certainly had royal taste in jewels. Taylor owned one of the most famous diamonds in the world - the 70 carat Taylor-Burton Diamond, a gift from her husband, Harry Burton, which she wore to the 42nd Academy Awards.

links.description: Before The Great (2020), Tony McNamara wrote The Favourite (2019), a story about another fashion-forward royal - Queen Anne. For her coronation, she wore a crimson cloak over a white satin dress, later changing into a lace gown to counterbalance the weight of the Royal Jewels.

links.description: Elizabeth Taylor was one of the first celebrities to publicly support HIV//AIDS activism. Activist organisation ACT UP adopted the pink triangle given to gay men in Nazi camps, in their protest against the government’s response to the AIDS crisis. ACT UP’s efforts were depicted in BPM (Beats Per Minute).
